characters: JOHN IS SUDDENLY STARTLED BY A NOISE FROM THE STUDY
COMPUTER IS SEARCHING FOR A MATCH.
SHOTGUN RATCHETING A ROUND IN THE CHAMBER.
A DISTINCTIVE BURN SCAR GRADUALLY MORPHING ONTO JOHN'S DE
WE HEAR JOHN'S WORDS ECHO IN FRANK'S HEAD
ANOTHER FINGER PRESSING DOWN ON THE RED SQUAWK BAR... FRA
IN SHOCK AS HIS HAND BEGINS TO DISFIGURE.
NIGHTINGALE MURDERS, WOMEN'S JEWELRY, NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS
SHEPARD RIGHT HAND GOES LIMP AROUND JOHN'S NECK. HE STAR

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: The legend reads: OCTOBER 10th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness.  Headlights bounce off thick sheets of RAIN.  6 gallon Esso OIL TRUCK barrels over wet studded pavement, heading towards Manhattan.  It's going fast.  Too fast. Up ahead...at the BASE OF THE BRIDGE: A large reflective sign - lit up by arc lights: MEN AT WO There are TWO WORK CREWS, several hundred feet apart. THE FIRST CREW is CON ED.  A corrugated vacuum tube feeds into an open MANHOLE.  A WORKER drops into the hole. THE SECOND CREW is CONSTRUCTION.  They're at the apron of bridge securing lumber supports for the roadbed. It's late and the men are tired.  A mistake is made.  A F LIFT loaded with LUMBER fails to negotiate a turn...whack into an abutment... spilling its load onto the roadway. Bad timing, because right now that Esso OIL TRUCK hits th OFF RAMP.  Not a lot of time for the driver to react to a roadway spewed with lumber. He does his best.  Slams the brakes, spins the wheel, hit the horn, but it doesn't matter: 18 wheels skid across th blacktop - spitting thick smoke and burnt rubber, lifting the slick pavement...twisting...flipping...hemorrhaging o from its ruptured tanks...grinding its way towards... MEN AT WORK.  Seconds to react as an 80,000 pound juggern of death plows through parked cars like paper...crushing Con Ed equipment...lurching to a halt on top of the MANHO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO FIRE TRUCKS (1000 Gallon Pumper and Mack Tiller Ladde pull into the street.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: SIRENS wail, cherry tops spin. FRANK SULLIVAN, 40, is strapped into an open-air jumper s A real life hard charger, Frank is the kind of iron's man fire fighters want coming in after them, should they get caught in harm's way.  Kind-hearted and hard-fisted, he h the grace and courage of a man living by his convictions. Across from Frank sits GRAHAM GIBSON, 20.  A good-looking African-American, "Gib" is a Fire Fighter Fourth Grade, a tank man... and one nervous probie. Through a window into the CAB, we SEE LT. BUTCH FOSTER, 5 on a walkie-talkie.  A beefy old pro who's been through m fires than he can remember. A walkie-talkie sits in a cradle between Frank and Gibson

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through walkie-talkie) ...oil all over the street.  Cracked water and gas mains.  Four companies coming in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch's voice continues as Frank calmly absorbs the information, while at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: rain) Oh, man.  Hope it ain't like this in Baltimore tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baltimore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game, Graham.  The Series?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibson taps his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.  Damn.  My watch is busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rookie.  Be cool.  Just stay with me.  This is what we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still tapping his watch) I seem nervous, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank laughs.  Gibson grins, relaxes a bit.  Frank checks ROLEX DIVER'S WATCH.  Multiple SIRENS fill the dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 5:30, Gib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through walkie talkie) ...two Con Ed men trapped in an underground electrical conductor vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's eyes harden.  His game face sets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tableau of impending danger.  Thick black OIL bleeds fr teh truck onto the street...pouring underneath the rig... into the MANHOLE. POLICE urgently cordon off the area, evacuating the worke EMERGENCY PERSONNEL deal with the badly injured TRUCK DRI Firemen wedge sandbags between the hull of the truck and three-quarters covered manhole -- trying to divert the oi away from the underground vault. FIRE COMMANDER O'CONNELL yells at his men to finish the j and get the hell away. The BIG TRUCKS ARRIVE.  PUMPER ENGINE and Frank's LADDER TRUCK -- rapidly guided into position by men on the groun Frank, Gibson, Butch and the rest of the unit are on the ground instantly and ready for orders.  They are looking nightmare ready to happen.  Frank takes in everything. FIRE COMMANDER O'CONNELL and a CON ED SUPERVISOR approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep irony) A fun one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got high voltage cables ripped loose in the underground.  They hit water, that fault's gonna arc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks at the tanker over the manhole.  There is now nobody around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why haven't they killed the juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switches are shorted out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shitting me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I was.  Oldest part of the system down there.  We're on it, but it's gonna take awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta go underground.  Get those guys out, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried.  Bulkhead door's rusted shut. Won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The block is being evacuated.  I don't want anybody... including our boys...within fifty yards of that tanker...it's a fucking bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank has been staring at the capsized rig. Butch knows what he's thinking.  But it's too late.  Fran gone...slogging through the oozing oil to the hull of the tanker.  He kneels over the three-quarters covered manhol using a flashlight to peer into the darkness below.  Spar from the loose cables spit off flashes of light as the ca hiss and slap against the ceiling and walls of the vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Fire Department.  Frank Sullivan.  You guys okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please man, you gotta get us out of here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what we're gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Frank is up, heading for his truck, signaling Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells to Con Ed Supervisor) How do we get to the vault door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a manhole at Canal and Bowery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, Frank.  No way you reach those men in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank grabs a "halaghan claw tool" and a walkie-talkie. Gibson nervously picks out two helmet lights...and they a off and running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling back) I can do it, Butch.  Me and my 'tank man' here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all, and into walkie) Start spraying down the street.  Let me know when we are fully evacuated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank uses the "adz" to rip open the heavy manhole cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Gibson descend into the tunnel, strap lights on their leather helmets to illuminate the damp darkness.  T race down the subterranean passage.  The stench is thick. Butch's voice suddenly booms out of the walkie-talkie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (via walkie) Frank, you hear me?  Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Yeah, Butch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (via walkie) The gas level is getting serious. The underground's combustible - it could flashover.  I want you to abort!  Now! Get the hell out of there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank picks up the pace.  Charges ahead.  Guy's got balls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Frank.  We gotta go back.  Frank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back to him) Stay with me, Gib.  We're gonna do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charging after him) I should'a been a fucking mailman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank reaches the rusted 'submarine-like' VAULT DOOR.  Po on the door... a faint response.  He goes to work on it w the halaghan tool.  Gibson arrives...pretty rattled.  Fra gives him a wink and a smile.  It's gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (via walkie) Frank, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank digs down, suddenly the DOOR GIVES WAY Oil and water rush from the VAULT, pouring over Frank and Gibson, foaming into the tunnel.  But the door is mounted three feet off the ground.  There is still three feet of and water trapped inside.  And the smell of gas is now overwhelming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) We're in, Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank probes the dark vault with the FLASHLIGHT BLADE. Through smoke we see TWO MEN huddled in the corner, trapp by three loose 'HOT' CABLES - WHIPPING AROUND THE TINY VA LIKE AN ELECTRIC HYDRA.  Con Ed Worker #2 shivers, ankle broken, leaning on older Con Ed Worker #1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to go home, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibson sprays the room, clearing out most of the smoke. Frank steps into the vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful.  If the hot end of those cables hits you, it'll conduct to the water and we're all fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drops to his knees, ducking under the cables, shuff to center of the vault.  Places his hands at opposite end the halaghan tool, hoping for the cables to pass directly over his head.  A hairy beat, then... Frank jackknifes out of the water, ramming the halaghan i the ceiling.  It worked.  The teeth on the "claw-end" and spike on the "adz-end" are embedded into the concrete -- STAPLING THE CABLES TO THE CEILING.  Make that balls of steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Gibby!  Everybody move it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibson and Con Ed worker #1 help injured Worker #2 out of vault.  Frank checks to make sure they've cleared the vau and lets go of the tool. Frank jumps into the tunnel, hoists the injured worker ov his back and races back down the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gibson) Haul ass, that claw ain't gonna hold for long... (into walkie) Take cover -- she's gonna flash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Connell and the few remaining cops & firemen run for it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Gibson and the Con Ed men scramble towards the manhole.  Butch and another fireman are waiting up top. help the men -- who are covered in oil and slime -- up on the street.  And then they all tear away from the manhole...around a corner... collapsing on the pavement against a building.

dialogues.speaker: K-A-B-O-O-M
dialogues.text: The vault ignites, the tunnel "FLASHBACKS" -- a towering geyser of FLAMES AND DIRT ERUPTING out of the manhole fro which Frank has just escaped. In the distance, FLAMES erupt out of the other manhole...engulfing the OIL TRUCK...blowing it into a mil pieces. Through the INFERNO at the base of the Manhattan Bridge, Frank can see that no one is hurt.  His eyes glistening w adrenaline and relief, he sits back against the building throws an arm around Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did good, Gib.  Real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks over at the hyperventilating Butch and smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis has left the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the tunnel.  Dark.  Moving fast.  Flashes of LIGHT bounce off the shiny tile walls.  The deep throated ROAR '67 HARLEY battles with Martha & the Vandellas' HEAT WAVE We are with Frank, wearing a leather jacket with the insi of his fire-fighting unit emblazoned on it, and a New Yor Mets BASEBALL CAP pulled down tight, as he rockets his chopper through traffic, out of the tunnel, and up into..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREDIT MONTAGE begins as Frank cruises home.  It has STOP RAINING.  Frank passes by billboards and other evidence o the approaching METS/BALTIMORE ORIOLES World Series. He circles a LITTLE LEAGUE ball field waving to some OLDSTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank glides the Harley alongside his house.  A feisty DALMATIAN PUPPY ELVIS barks his welcome from behind a fen Feeling fatigued, Frank dismounts and enters teh backyard playing for a moment with Elvis while he uprights a TRAIN BICYCLE, tidies up BASEBALL EQUIPMENT, and glances up at HAM RADIO ANTENNA secured to the roof, before entering through a backdoor.  There is a sense of routine to all t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is empty.  Breakfast dishes in the sink.  Fra flips on the RADIO.  It plays out under the rest of the MONTAGE as coverage of the oil truck crash blends into ot news stories. A note on the refrigerator reads: 8:15.  Hey, Bud.  I'm o to work. Johnny's at school.  Elvis is fed.  I luvs you. Setting a grapefruit and a slice of toast on the table, F glances at the Daily News.  But his eyes are tired, he st off into space...letting go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radio in the bedroom is tuned to sports news.  Frank so in a hot bath.  He looks like he might fall asleep - and does. CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH!  A SOFTBALL BLOWS through the window from the BACKYARD, landing on the rug next to the bed.  Frank bolt awake, staring at the busted window. He checks the clock.  It is 5:15.  He steps to the broken window.  SEVERAL SMALL BOYS scurry from the yard.  Two others, JOHNNY SULLIVAN and GORDO HERSCH, both 6, stand frozen in place.  Elvis tears in circles around them.  Al very quiet.  Then, from somewhere beyond the bedroom door HEAR The Beatles' BACK IN THE THE USSR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA SULLIVAN, 32, is rockin' out, chopping vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to song) ...show me 'round the smokey mountains way down south...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adorable, sweet and strong.  Strawberry blonde hair, sapp eyes, soft earthy vibe.  A beauty. Frank, wearing FDNY sweats, moves into the kitchen flippi the softball from hand to hand.  Julia turns to him and r her eyes at the sight of the ball.  Say no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without breaking stride, he gives her a smack on the lips steps to the screen door to the back porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny stands nervously outside the door.  Elvis sits at side.  Gordo watches from the safety of his own porch nex door.  Frank opens the screen door, casts a stern look do at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like two weeks worth of allowance, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Sorry, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Frank drops the softball into Johnny's mitt, closes t screen door and turns back into the kitchen.  Johnny turn away into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a shrug, and sharing a kids will be kids smile with Julia, he grabs a cold Rheingold from the refrigerator an heads into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...past a CONSOLE TELEVISION, to the HI-FI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Julia) How about a little of the King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from kitchen) Well, why not a little of the King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia crosses her eyes, as if she could stop him.  Frank moves to change records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a PAN of spaghetti sauce bubbles over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I ruined the sauce...again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Elvis' SUSPICIOUS MINDS plays, Frank steps back in, mo up behind Julia, and takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Jules?  Trouble workin' an eight hour shift, watching the kid and whipping up a little bolognese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't marry Donna Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd go with you and Chinese take-out over her any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he turns her around and they start to dance as Frank sings along to Elvis, badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing lyrics) Caught in a trap, I can't walk out, because I love you too much b-b-baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the music as it drifts out into the YARD where can SEE Johnny and Gordo looking in at the weirdness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank spots Johnny and Gordo staring at them.  He winks a the boys and swings Julia into a Fred Astaire dip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loaded) Butch called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was under control, Bud.  Butchy's just getting tight in his old age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong with old age, Frank...long as you get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a laugh, Frank drops Julia into another dip.  As the music fades, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: BICYCLE TRAINING WHEELS lying on the sidewalk. Johnny is precariously perched on his fire engine red BICYCLE.  He wears a police badge and a whistle around hi neck.  Frank stands beside him, holding on to the bike se We're on a quiet side street next to house.  It's the las light of the day. Hold on Johnny's eyes...fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, start pedaling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy put the wheels back on.  I'm gonna fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think about falling, just keep pedaling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Chief, show some guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny takes a gulp of air, doesn't want to disappoint hi father, nods okay. He starts pedaling.  Slowly moving forward.  Frank holds to the seat.  Frank's still hanging on - jogging along si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna let go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank let's go.  Johnny's pumping those little six year-o legs, but he starts to wobble out of control -- CRASH! Johnny starts to cry, quickly gets up and runs back to th house.  Julia comes out of the kitchen door.  Johnny runs into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't quit on me now, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny tears himself from Julia's arms, runs inside. Frustrated, Frank lights up another cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so tough on him Frank, he's six years old. (softer) He just needs to know you're right there behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank takes a deep drag on the butt.  Steps onto the YARD stares up at the starry night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY'S POV: Frank standing in the yard, wishing on a st Johnny looks up at the sky and makes a wish of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countless points of light blaze across vast blackness.  A luminous blue sphere floats peacefully below EARTH.  We a 22,000 miles away in geosynchronous orbit. MULTI-BILLION DOLLAR PIECE OF HARDWARE drifts into and fi the frame - 1 1960's COMMUNICATION SATELLITE, NASA & HUGH logos affixed to the glistening aluminum hull. All is still for some moments.  But then a sound disturbs quiet of the cosmos.  It's coming from the horizon.  From something that looks like a hole in the fabric of space. Bright streaks of starlight swirl around into that hole. And slowly the satellite begins drifting towards it - pul in by some invisible force. FOLLOW THE SATELLITE AS IT IS SUCKED INTO THE VORTEX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look through the ripple of warped space-time.  As if holding a lens to one eye, we glimpse two earths at once two identical North Americas.  The two earths turn slightly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the screen door, we are CLOSE ON A MAN'S FACE, staring out... JOHN F. SULLIVAN, 35.  John's eyes tell us needs more than just a shave and a good night's sleep.  T man has demons.  Right now he is LOOKING OUT AT: SAMANTHA TAYLOR, 33.  A knockout.  Dark blonde hair, pier blue eyes.  Not happy.  She jams a suitcase into the back seat of her car and starts back for the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that's it, Sam?  You're just walking out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha strides in past John towards a washer/dryer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been walking out for the last six months.  You didn't notice...or care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs clothes from teh dryer and exits to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...towards a stairway beyond, John not far behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, go ahead and save the whole world, Sam. (sipping his beer) You don't gotta worry about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you.  I tried.  But you wouldn't help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha steps into the bedroom to an open suitcase and travel bag.  She starts jamming the clean clothes into th suitcase and then begins to close the case and bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  We should've quit a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam can't hold back anymore - she cries openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault.  It's mine.  I can't change.  Wish I could, Sam.  But I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly Samantha's tears turn to anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John has no reply.  All he can do is watch as she takes h stuff and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stands immobilized in the middle of the room.  He lo down and spots a TEDDY BEAR half stuck under a reading ch And then to a photo of him and Sam at a CARNIVAL SHOOTING GALLERY.  Sam's holding the teddy bear.  John turns at th SOUND of the backdoor slamming.  Looks out a window down Samantha getting in her car and driving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John enters, goes straight for a half empty bottle of BUSHMILLS IRISH WHISKEY.  As he brings the bottle to his mouth...BRRRRING.  The PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swigging Bushmills as he steps to a combination portable phone/answering machine, John takes off his jacket.  We notice two things: an NAPPED DETECTIVE SHIELD and a .38 REVOLVER. BRRIING.  John grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  It don't matter, Lady.  Why?... Cause I don't got no friends or family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG.  Slams down the phone.  And stares around the room. WE'VE BEEN IN THIS HOUSE BEFORE -- 29 YEARS AGO.  This wa Frank and Julia sullivan's house.  Time has not been good it.  Furnishings haven't changed much, but the house is missing the warmth it had when a family filled it with lo John's eyes dart to a PHOTOGRAPH next to the desk.  It is picture of THE SULLIVAN FAMILY from back then.  Too many memories.  He grabs his coat, heads out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field is EMPTY.  Covered in shadows.  John sits alone the top row of the BLEACHERS, cradling his bottle of BUSHMILLS.  He takes a long pull.  As he stares down at t empty field, his eyes slowly drift over to home plate... AUDIO FLASHBACK: a VOICE rises up out of the darkness.  T voice of memory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batting next.  Johnny Sullivan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the SOUNDS of CHEERING parents.  The CLAPPING, WHISTLING & SHOUTING is hauntingly juxtaposed against the empty playing field and bleachers we see on the screen. CRACK: sound of the bat solidly connecting with the ball. CAMERA follows invisible runner from home to first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sullivan's safe at first.  Batting for Johnny's father is...Coach Newman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John takes a deep breath, glances from first base back to home plate...then looks off into the distance - a cold thousand yard stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John shuffles up the pathway.  The SOUND of a TV - X-FILE filters out from inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks in the front door.  GORDY JR., 8, carrying an overstuffed BLT, whizzes by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Uncle John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John notices smoke filtering out of his kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your uncle, kid. (yelling into kitchen) Gordo, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully!  Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow John into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet GORDON HERSCH, 35, computer geek, lovable dough boy. Last seen by us in 1969 as a six-year old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sull.  My cable's out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John glances at a mound of burnt bacon dripping on the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe Ellen still won't let me cook in the house?  I melt one lousy frying pan, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy Jr. scoots into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, guess what?  Dad's taking me fishing.  Wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I could, Gordy.  But you bring me back a big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, OK if Gordy uses your old gear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's somewhere in the closet... if you can find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy Jr. runs out.  O.S. sounds of him rummaging through hall closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Yahoo went up another two points. Man, did we miss the boat on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John puts the Bushmills bottle down, and grabs two Molson

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda, woulda, shoulda, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John laughs, hands Gordo a beer, and lights up a cigarett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam called Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John reacts.  Nothing else needs to be said.  A beat, the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come with us?  Three days of fresh air and barbecue would do you some good, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, John, c'mere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy Jr. sticks out of the closet, attempting to drag ou large BLACK STEAMER TRUNK, stenciled with yellow letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Gordy, what 'ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, check it out.  Fire Department!  Can I open it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John thinks about it for a second.  Noting the curious gl in little Gordy's face, nods OK. Gordy Jr. pops open the latches, opens the trunk.  Gordo crouches down beside his son, checks out the dusty conten HOLD ON JOHN'S REACTION to what Gordy Jr. finds in the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy Jr. reaches in and takes out: FDNY HELMET & JACKETS Briefly puts on the enormous helmet, then sets it aside. Reaches back into the trunk and pulls out the disassemble pieces of a 12 gauge SHOTGUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Gimmie that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo takes the shotgun from the boy and places it ginger inside the closet. Simultaneously, Gordy Jr. hands off a leather-bound SCRAP to John.  Before John can react, Gordy Jr. lifts up an AMATEUR RADIO TRANSCEIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powerful memories fill his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, that's your Dad's old ham radio. Remember?  Remember how we used to beg him to let us talk on that thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the transceiver and microphone - mint condition 1965 Yaes 101, and a "Silver Eagle" Astatic D-104 microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we try it Dad, can we try it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo looks at John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glass doors separate the study from the family room.  The RADIO is set on a dusty wooden desk.  Scotch-taped to the of the radio is a diagram for the radio setup and "QSL" cards: certificates from around the world acknowledging "contact" with "WB2YXB" -- FRANK SULLIVAN, BAYSIDE NY. Gordo hooks up the radio.  Gordy Jr. shuts off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this was what people used before the Net, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, do I feel old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORDO TURNS THE RADIO ON.  Shows Gordy how it works.  Gor rotates the tuning dial, nothing but "dead bands."  STATI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's junk, kid.  Nobody uses those things anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KNOCK.  Front door opens.  John's head turning around.  M ELLEN, 35, Gordo's wife.  The grown-up in the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo, do you know what time it is? (a beat) Hi, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen notices John's weary look but says nothing.  We get sense she knows what is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Gordy, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo and family pour into the yard between the two house John shuffles out behind them.  Gordo and Gordy Jr. quick disappear into their house, but Ellen lingers for a momen looking back at John standing alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen holds her glance for a moment.   John smiles, thinl masking his sadness.  Ellen nods okay, and she is gone. looks up at the stars, then down to the HAM RADIO ANTENNA his roof, now looking raggedy from 29 years of neglect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV: LARRY KING is interviewing STEPHEN HAWKING. John is back on the Bushmills.  He races clumsily for the CORDLESS PHONE.  CLOSE ON SPEED DIAL BUTTONS.  John hits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering machine voice) Hi, this is Julia.  Please leave a message after the tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ma, it's me.  Checking in.  Probably at work.  Anyways, I'll see you tomorrow night.  Love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John puts down the phone.  Stares at the FDNY trunk.  He stumbles to it.  Sits down and opens it up.  It's filled his Dad's stuff.  He picks up and leafs through the old SCRAPBOOK - PHOTOS and CLIPPINGS illustrate FAMILY HISTOR A quick glimpse of Dad's high school baseball team; Mom a Dad's 60's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: John at his First Communion pictured with his MOTHER - WE SENSE LOSS AND SADNESS IN HIS EYES - THIS BOY LOOKS HURT. A folded newspaper drops out.  John picks it up.  Front p of the DAILY NEWS.  Top half READS: "October 13, 1969. AMAZIN'S TAKE GAME 2 - SERIES EVEN."  The lower half READ

dialogues.speaker: "FIREMAN KILLED IN WAREHOUSE BLAZE"
dialogues.text: He shoves the paper back in the scrapbook.  Puts the albu down - he can't deal with those wounds.  He glances up at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this anomaly connected to the space storm and the NASA satellite that disappeared in 1969?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know.  But given the similarities of their location and appearance, this is a question that merits further investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE:  Larry King's show plays for the duration of this scene. John settles in, takes off his work shirt.  Underneath he on a T-shirt.  We notice a NICOTINE PATCH on his arm. Doesn't stop him from burning another Marlboro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over radio) CQ 15, here is WB2YXB, by for call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John gets up, Bushmill bottle in hand, and stumbles into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CQ 15, come in 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approaching the desk, John sits down at the radio.  Reach out to the mic -- presses down on the red squawk bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WB2YKXB, who've I got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly slurred) Name's John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the BACKGROUND of FRANK'S VOICE, we barely hear WALTER CRONKITE interviewing someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you licensed to broadcast, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't really remember how this thing works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you can't broadcast without a license.  Unless this is an emergency, you gotta get off the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Pal, my whole life's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you transmitting from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queens, New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta ya know.  Bayside, born and raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought these things were for talkin' around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15-band closes down at night.  During the day you can chew the band with China if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe people are still using these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As John releases the squawk bar, the distant sound of Fra TV filters out of the HAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hold on a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then John hears the sound of a door closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry 'bout that.  So Queens, you psyched for the Series?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a swig) I don't really follow baseball anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got fed up with all the bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fed up?  Lemme tell you something, in a 1000 years, when school kids study America, they're gonna learn about three things: the Constitution, Rock 'n' Roll, and Baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite his mood, John has to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you live in Queens and not love the Amazin's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John warms to the topic of his boyhood heroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're talking The Amazin' Mets, well, that's different.  You know people talk about Seaver, but I'll love Ron Swoboda til the day I die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Static crackles out over the radio.  The signal weakens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through static) I'm right with you, man.  He's got the heart of a lion.  Hey, how 'bout the first game of the Series?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It was all over after Buford nailed Seaver's first pitch outta the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way, brother.  Ain't gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BZZZSSSSHHHH - loud static.  THE SIGNAL IS GONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind him, on TV, Larry King and Hawking continue talkin

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER FINGER PRESSING DOWN ON THE RED SQUAWK BAR... FRA
dialogues.text: SULLIVAN.  Seated at the polished wooden desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Queens.  You there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  The signal is gone.  Frank leans forward, jiggl the frequency dial, trying to regain the signal.  No luck Slightly frustrated, he stands and opens the glass doors the family room where Julia is watching TV - a very young STEPHEN HAWKING is being interviewed by WALTER CRONKITE,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie, Johnny wants to say goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little distracted) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to take a step into the room, and stumbles over Elvis, sleeping by the door...KNOCKING INTO and CRACKING GLASS PANE in one door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, dog tired and more than a little wasted, gets up fr the desk, inadvertently leaving the Ham Radio ON, and shuffles for the family room through the glass doors. CAMERA HOLDS, CLOSE on the GLASS PANE...CRACKED in the ex same spot where Frank knocked into it 29-YEARS AGO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank unpins the police badge from Johnny's shirt, takes whistle from around his neck.  He pulls up the covers and softly kisses Johnny's forehead.  You can tell he loves t kid more than anything in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lullaby-like) Take me out to the ballgame, take me out with the crowd.  Buy me some peanuts and cracker jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John plops down on sofa, half asleep.  The TV drones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't care if I never get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LEGEND reads: OCTOBER 11th - FIRST GAME OF THE WORLD SERIES Blue sky.  A SOFTBALL soars into view.  It drops down and into a WILLIE MAYS' style basket catch by Frank Sullivan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same Little League field that Frank circled on his Ha yesterday, October 10, 1969.  And the same field at which John sat in the stands drinking last night, October 10, 1 We are in the 9th inning of a friendly SOFTBALL GAME betw the local COPS and FIREMEN.  A lot of NYPD and FDNY T-shi sweats and caps.  Plenty of Mets stuff, too. Having made the catch, Frank coolly pulls the ball from h mitt as he starts running toward the infield diamond. Tagging up at 3rd, sorely tempted to try for home is SATC DELEON, 30, NYPD Detective.  Satch feints for the plate, Frank feints the throw.  For a maddening, gleeful moment, Frank has Satch caught between 3rd and home. In the STANDS, Johnny Sullivan, Marge Hersch and the FAMI of the other ballplayers scream for whomever they want to this game of chicken. On the SIDELINES, Johnny, Gordo and the other KIDS servin BATBOYS and WATERBOYS, jump around in anticipation. At HOME, Butch Foster stations himself to take the throw. Suddenly, Satch fakes to 3rd, then bolts for home.  Frank pegs it to Butch, who tags the sliding Satch.  Game over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky throw, fire boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jogging in) Luck, my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They square off.  Pretending to fight.  Julia steps betwe them.  And they all descend into laughter. Frank and Satch each wrap an arm around Julia and start o Within a step, Johnny slips in under Frank's other arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) See that, kid.  Practice.  Practice.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BUTCH'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Close on a TV: PRESIDENT NIXON tosses the first ball to o the 1969 WORLD SERIES. REVERSE to see many of the PLAYERS and FAMILIES from teh softball game are parked around a couple of TVs watching game.  BEER flows from a keg.  SOFT DRINKS are passed aro HAMBURGERS and HOT DOGS are cooking on the BBQ. Satch sits with Johnny and Gordo and some other kids. Frank and Julia tend the BBQ.  Butch brings out some beer A fun day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DETECTIVE'S CAR pulls up next to a couple of BLUE & WHI at West 155th St.  The Northern tip of Manhattan Island. Across construction barricades is a half-torn down GREEK RESTAURANT.  Several UNIFORMS can be seen beyond it, look at something on the ground. As John exits the car, the passenger door swings open and MEET a guy we haven't seen in 29 YEARS - SATCHEL DELEON, Shaved head, square jaw.  A ram-rod straight, craggy warr Thirty-plus years on the force now endow him with a rare combination of smarts, guts and sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they walk) Don't choke on your pride, Sull.  You ain't ever gonna catch another one like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She made up her mind.  Nothin' I do is gonna change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing you're willing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotting John and Satch, a UNIFORM approaches them.  They keep on walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Survey crew found a body.  Actually a skeleton.  Over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uniform leads John and Satch around some overgrown we to SEE a patch of freshly unearthed dirt...out of which sticks a HUMAN SKULL and COLLAR BONE. In the B.G., a CRIME SCENE unit can be seen arriving by v

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be real careful when pulling it out.  And get the dirt around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Satch turns to talk to a second UNIFORM and a couple o SURVEYORS, John notices a man raking leaves in a yard not away.  As he starts to him, to Satch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll visit the neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON FRED SHEPARD, 72.  As the scene unfolds, we can the half torn down diner/crime scene through a window.  S oversees the operation. MRS. SHEPARD, 70, hands John a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to get breakfast there all the time back from the boat.  Them Greeks were good people.  Once that McDonalds opened up on Dyckman, they lost all their business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John glances around the room - notes family PHOTOGRAPHS. There's a picture of Shepard in younger days on a commerc fishing boat.  Next to it a faded black and white picture Mrs. Shepard, 35.  A few pictures of the Shepards and the YOUNG SON.  And at the end, a color photograph of the sam son, about 20, in DRESS BLUES, graduating from the Police Academy - CLASS OF '64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son on the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was.  Carl died in the line of duty. October '69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shepard points to a frame above the fireplace: Distinguis Service Medal, CARL SHEPARD, awarded posthumously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy lived and bled blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  Mr. and Mrs. Shepard stand very still.  John discreetly glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER in the distance.  CRIME SCENE personnel have made some progress in unearthing the skeletal remains.  A coup of drops of rain tap the ground and the bones. John stands looking down at the skeleton.  A long beat. then he turns to Satch and they start for the car.  Behin them, the skeleton is carefully pulled free from the grou WE SEE its wrists are BOUND with GLASS TAPE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHINESE TAKE-OUT CARTONS are placed in a microwave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the woman holding the cartons: JULIA SULLIVAN, 29 YEARS O than the last time we saw her.  But she looks okay, she l happy. We are in the kitchen of Julia's Upper West Side apartmen It is raining.  We notice THE GEORGE WASHINGTON BRIDGE outside a BAY WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) I thought it'd be nicer to eat here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking into the other room) I'm sorry Sam couldn't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying badly) Yeah, those grad school applications are driving her crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia hands John a Coke.  Close on her face - she feels h son's pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure everything'll work out. (beat) She really loves you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) So how are things at the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  You know Dr. Schwartz retired last month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidd'n, he musta been pushing 90!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how'd you like LION KING?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I loved it.  I wish you'd gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I'm sorry.  Work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work too hard, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a laugh.  And then slowly the laughter dies. John's expression changes as he quietly lights a cigarett Julia knows what he's thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29-years tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could remember him better. Truth is, most of the stuff I know is from the stories you used to tell.  But they're not mine.  They're not my memories.  They're yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia glances at an old photo of Frank, then back to John

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would have liked him, John.  And he would have liked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PING.  The microwave timer sounds off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's dog, Elvis.  Poking his nose in a carton of Chine take-out on the floor.  An arm drops into frame - scruffs puppy's back.  The Rolex diver's watch tells us the arm belongs to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sitting at his desk.  He fires up an unfiltered LUC STRIKE, pops a Rheingold.  Next to him a Daily News headl NASA INVESTIGATES SPACE STORM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...WB2YXB calling unidentified station, Queens.  CQ 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over radio, sounds like he's had a few drinks) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been Q-ing you all night.  How the hell did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The World Series.  You called Buford's homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't too tough, buddy.  Game happened almost thirty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  I'm talking about this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank puts his finger on the squawk bar, about to say something, but just at that moment his son Johnny appears the doorway in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, come up and sing the baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) I'll be up soon, Little Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Sullivan's face, thunderstruck.  The camera stays on John.  He puts down his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry 'bout that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you just say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was my kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks up at the photo on the wall: FRANK, JULIA AND YEAR OLD JOHNNY SULLIVAN (CIRCA 1969).  A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call your son Little Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank...Frank Sullivan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of joke?  Gordo is that you?  Are you fucking with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look pal, I'm just askin' how you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me your name is Frank Sullivan, you live in Queens and you just saw the first game of the '69 Series...live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right...and I'm asking how you called the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo, if this is you, so help me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does Gordy have to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's POV - top of radio - in FADED PEN, on a piece of masking tape, is written: "WB2YXB"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say your station...uh, your call letters were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The call letters hang in the air.  A breath, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you listen to me.  My name is John Francis Sullivan, I live at 1060 41st, where I've lived my whole life.  And I saw the first game of the '69 Series at my Uncle Butch's house with my father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29-years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank dropping his cigarette in the ashtray.  It rolls ou and lies smoldering on the desk.  He doesn't even notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 years...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad's name was Frank Patrick Sullivan, he was a fire fighter and a die-hard Mets fan.  And every night when I went to bed he sang to me... (softly, almost singing) Take me out to the ball game, take me out with the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dreaming this.  Shit, this is a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John reaches out to touch the radio.  But he stops, his h hovering just above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're Frank Sullivan, huh?  It's 1969 and you're sitting at your desk in the study, just chewin' the rag?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON FRANK.
dialogues.text: He smells smoke, sees the cigarette burning a hole in the desk.  Spooked, Smokey the Bear just started a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank beats out the flame with the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) Nothing...I just spilled something.

dialogues.speaker: A DISTINCTIVE BURN SCAR GRADUALLY MORPHING ONTO JOHN'S DE
dialogues.text: John pushes the Bushmills to the side, staring at the sca It hits him - hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just burned the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John rubs his fingers over the old burn scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You burnt the desk...I can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eerie quiet, the only sound is the rain outside John's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it's not...

dialogues.speaker: ON JOHN
dialogues.text: reaching out, touching the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shockwave.  A long moment of absorption.  INTERCUT Frank John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could this be happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta be bouncing off the mother sun spot of all time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun spot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's how Hams work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a sec...there was something on the news.  Something about this space anomaly.  I think they said it was connected to some storm in '69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank glances at DAILY NEWS HEADLINE - SPACE STORM.  He s nothing for a long beat, struggling to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound...ground up...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thirty-five years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-five?  That would make it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls back from the radio...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1998...?  This is wrong.  Who are you? Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing anything. (beat) Look, I don't know what's going on.  But I swear on my life, I"m here at your old desk, on your Ham, in our house, right now...in 1998.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's voice has a conviction that Frank cannot deny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really you, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  Both men trying to wrap their minds around the reality of the situation.  Slowly accepting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-five?  Jesus, you're almost as old as I am... (long beat) What's your life like?  You married?  Got kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too busy playin' ball, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I gave it up.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRANK
dialogues.text: Johnny gave up baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John takes a sip, the answer caught in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still my Little Chief, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to be, Dad.  I'm tyrin'. (pausing) It's good to hear your voice. (quiet beat) I missed you...so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet beat.  A burst of static crackles the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: static) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm losing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wait, don't go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  I'm still here, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not...you're not still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More static.  The signal breaks up, then returns weaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never knew you, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an abandoned warehouse - hit by lightening. (beat) Butch told Ma it was just one wrong turn. Said it wasn't your fault.  You went with the training, with your instincts. (beat) If you'd just gone left instead of right, you would've made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can't be...that's not gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did, Pop.  It did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 12, 1969.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy static now.  They can barely hear each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fully realizing) Tomorrow.  Jesus...it hasn't happened. It doesn't have to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men frantic.  Their words overlapping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go.  Don't go in that warehouse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final blast of static.  The SIGNAL is GONE.  The BAND is GONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight casts a glow over the sleeping Johnny.  Frank s in and stands looking down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John crawls out a window, through the rain, onto the roof

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusted Ham radio antenna, half-fallen over. John scoots over to it, straightening it.  But he slips, sliding down the roof, coming to rest against the chimney A light pops on from an upstairs window across the street Gordo appears in the window.  Does a double take when he John, sitting on the roof, soaked, drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sliding open window) Sull!  What the hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to him Gordo.  I talked to my Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo's heart starts to break.  His best friend has slipp over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, man.  Get inside.  I'll come over. We'll play some Nintendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I gotta tell him the address, so he doesn't go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go in where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warehouse.  Buxton seeds.  It's tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know pal.  I remember.  Twenty-nine years tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LEGEND reads: OCTOBER 12th - SECOND GAME OF THE WORLD SERIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK CLOUDS, EARTH SHATTERING THUNDER.  A massive BOLT O LIGHTNING rockets out of the menacing sky STRIKING THROUG WINDOW on the 3rd floor of the warehouse.  A FIRE BEGINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAME 2 plays on TV.  Butch, Gibson and the rest of the un sit around enjoying the game.  A very distracted Frank st watching from the doorway to the kitchen. We are in the bottom of the 9th with the Baltimore Oriole Brooks Robinson coming to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man. Robinson is gonna nail it and we're gonna be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY THE ALARM SOUNDS, moving the groaning firemen reluctantly to action, and freezing Frank in surging anxi Gibson is up and passing Frank...who begins to move like in a trance. A RAPID MONTAGE of Frank, Butch and the others readying t head out.  Gibson grabs a little TRANSISTOR RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move it, gentlemen...three alarm. Lit up abandoned warehouse.  West 49th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks like he's going to throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, lost in thought, rounds a corner towards the bar.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The LADDER & ENGINE trucks barrel out of the firehouse. As SIRENS SCREAM, Frank and Gibson secure themselves into position.  Gibson excitedly switches on his radio to the game.  He notes that Frank is not the least bit into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully, you cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank seems not to hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.  Hey, man.  You alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alright, Gibby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the RADIO we HEAR the last play of the game as Brook Robinson grounds out 3rd to 1st.  METS WIN!  CHEERS are h in the streets and from the CABS of the racing fire truck Gibson whoops it up.  Frank barely acknowledges the win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John moves through the crowd of cops - ad lib greetings - slides into a booth occupied by Satch and Gordo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get your roof fixed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John shoots a look at Gordo, who quickly changes the subj

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe it, Yahoo goes up another point today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Located off the East River in lower Manhattan.  The 9th Battalion Fire trucks are first on the scene.  A couple o GREEN & WHITES are already there, uniform cops keeping a onlookers at a safe distance. FLAMES shoot out from the 4th and 5th FLOOR WINDOWS. Starting to lick their way up to the 6th floor and roof. SMOKE billows out of the windows on the 3rd and 2nd floor Lighter smoke spirals out from the door on the 1st floor. Frank, Gibson and other firemen under Butch's command tak stock of the situation and start to deploy. HOSES are run from HYDRANTS to the PUMPER TRUCKS. The LADDER is swung into position for an assault on the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard's moving fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God it's abandoned. (to the men) Surround and drown...nobody goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank nods in agreement.  Directly above them, another BO OF LIGHTNING CRACKS through the darkening sky. A death shudder creeps up Frank's spine.  And for the fir time in his life, Frank Sullivan is SCARED SHITLESS. Frank stares up at the sky, transfixed.  THUNDER punches sky with a huge roar.  RAIN starts to fall. And in the distance, as if from inside the burning buildi a FAINT SCREAMING is first heard, and growing louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, out of the building runs a STONED TEENAGE GIRL screaming and babbling incoherently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  Help!  Oh, god.  Help.  She's up there.  She's trapped!  Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately galvanized, Frank moves to the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey.  It's gonna be okay.  We're gonna help.  Okay?   Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tell me, who's up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My girlfriend, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a room...an office...or something.  We live there.  Top floor.  Something fell on her.  I couldn't help her.  Please, you gotta...gotta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks to Butch.  A beat.  Butch gives him the nod. Frank and Gibson gear up and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize that if you'd bought a thousand dollars worth of Yahoo in '96, it'd be worth fifty-grand today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You doin' okay, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough day, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satch and Gordo nod in sympathy.  Gordo raises his glass. Satch and John follow.  A yearly ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Gibson step into the warehouse.  Butch behind t Flames haven't reached this area yet, but the ROAR of the fire above them is deafening, and smoke billows down THE STAIRWAY before them.  They sprint towards it and start u ONE FLOOR.  TWO FLOORS.  THREE FLOORS, and suddenly they face to face with a WALL OF FIRE blocking access to the 4 floor. Frank and Gibson stop and stare into the inferno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks open on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know what's behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One way to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he barrels through the line of fire onto the 4th floo Gibson starts to do the same when the 5th floor gives way above Frank, sending burning timber and debris cascading around him and cutting off Gibson's route. Now Frank's only way to go is up the stairs toward the 5t floor.  He turns to Gibson.  Coming up behind him is Butc Across a gulf of flames Frank yells and waves at them to the hell out.  And then suddenly, part of the 3rd floor around Gibson and Butch starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming over fire) Get out...while you still can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank turns and bolts for the 5th floor as a huge flaming BEAM CRASHES down onto the stairway behind him, forcing Gibson and Butch to scramble like hell back down the stai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) ...it's not your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire fighters are efficiently and expertly hard at it. Running out lines.  Extending ladders.  Moving a FIRE BOA into place - all communicating via walkie-talkies all on same frequency. The BIG LADDER is now in place.  As it telescopes up, the ROOF MAN, BILL CAWLEY, begins his climb. PUMP TRUCKS and THE FIRE BOAT keep pumping water onto the blaze.  But no matter.  For the moment, this is one OUT O CONTROL NIGHTMARE FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: Frank reaching the 5th floor.  It's an inferno.  He keeps moving, tearing up the stairs for the 6th floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over walkie) Gotta be another way up, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Then fuckin' find it. (heading in) I'm going for the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over walkie) Billy, you better get up top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROOF MAN edges up the ladder, as it telescopes above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Billy, Frank. I'm on my way. South side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching 6th floor) Glad to hear it.  See you on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRE has torched OPEN a GAPING HOLE IN THE ROOF. Frank peers around through the smoke and fire and rain. he sees, huddled in the temporary saftey of the corner of OFFICE, but trapped by a fallen CONDUIT, the GIRL, passed from smoke inhalation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I've found the girl.

dialogues.speaker: A HIPPIE CRASH PAD
dialogues.text: Frank dashes into the office and heaves the conduit off t girl.  He hoists her over his shoulder and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch and Gibson exit the warehouse past the HOSE CREW already working its way into the building. They look up to the top of the warehouse where the LADDER haltingly inching its way up the side of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire on this floor is now a raging inferno.  Flames s up from the stairway below through the open roof.  Surrou by fire, Frank, carrying the girl, strides for what looks like a WINDOW on the south side of the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) It's real hot in here, Billy.  I'm coming out quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But apprehension rips across Frank's eyes as he reaches t window and looks down to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top end of the ladder FROZEN some 10 FEET BELOW THE WINDOW.  BETWEEN WALKIE-TALKIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm jammed up here, Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch and Gibson are now by the base of the LADDER TRUCK which is near the canal side of the building.  Butch scre at the ladder OPERATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck, GINO!  Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gear box cracked, Butch.  We're fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Frank!  Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Butch.  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank clicks off the walkie-talkie and turns to survey th hell around him.  The STAIRWAY IS GONE. To the RIGHT is a DOOR, flames around it, but none coming from the room beyond it. To the LEFT, another DOOR, a metal one, this one surround by fire - flames licking out all around it from room beyo EASY CHOICE.  Frank turns, heads towards DOOR ON THE RIGH No.  Wait.  HE STOPS.  SOMETHING'S WRONG.  HEART POUNDING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...one wrong turn... (beat) If you'd just gone left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for the first time in his life, Frank Sullivan goes against his instincts and his training as he... TURNS BACK AROUND AND GOES THE OTHER WAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo is in the middle of a story when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...principal calls us in 'cause Gordy hacked into the school system - sent out a little X-rated e-mail. (nervous laughter) Scary, huh?  Eight-years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep him away from girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...something happens - TIME STUTTERS AND REPEATS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeat) Just keep him away from girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The effect is like a phonograph needle stuck in the groov It lasts only a second and nobody seems to notice.  Nobod except John, who looks wildly disoriented.  He grabs hold the edge of the table as if to keep his equilibrium. John breaks into a cold sweat.  His HEART POUNDING AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franks reaches the door on the LEFT.  White heat and flam shoot everywhere...A FUCKING FURNACE.  He tires to open i IT'S LOCKED!  WHAM!  Frank kicks at it.  WHAM!  WHAM!  Th door blows open and flames leap out, the energy of the bl tossing Frank and the unconscious girl back onto the floo fire surging over their heads.  But then... He sees something on the other side of the doorway, insid the room, on the far wall.: A SMALL METAL SWINGING DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank cradles the girl.  Gets down on his knees, crawling under the heat.  Reaching the SWINGING DOOR.  Pushes it o revealing: A smooth metal SPIRAL SEED BAG CHUTE. Frank rips open his jacket and bundles the girl to him. works himself and the girl onto the top of the chute. The ROOM BEGINS TO SHAKE.  BRICKS TUMBLE OUT OF THE WALL. The whole GODDAMN BUILDING is going to COLLAPSE. Frank lurches forward until he and the girl start to move down the chute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank and the girl plunge through the bowels of the inferno...large portions of the building begins disintegrating around them...a giant storm of BRICKS, MOR METAL AND BURNING WOOD biting their tails... Gaining speed through each up-rushing floor...5-4-3-2...F and the girl zoom down towards the END OF THE SLIDE only find IT'S BOARDED UP.  OH SHIT! Frank grips the girl tight, raises his BOOTS, bends his knees, and like a HUMAN BATTERING RAM, SMASHES THROUGH TH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY'RE AIRBORNE.  Frank and the girl.  Floating in SLOW MOTION out over the CANAL and landing in the water betwee the WAREHOUSE DOCK and the FIREBOAT. A YELL snaps Butch's and Gibson's attention to what is happening.  Gibson starts running for the CANAL, ripping his coat and hat before leaping into the water.  But Fran getting pulled down by his fire tank and the weight of th girl.  Finally, Gibson reaches him, taking the girl.  Fra quickly sheds his jacket and the tank. Butch stands watching on the dock.  He takes a moment to close his eyes in thankful prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to giggle) Elvis has left the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitting the water has shot the girl back to consciousness look passes between her and Gibson.  A look he won't forg SILENCE.  Then the thunderous SOUND of the WAREHOUSE CAVI IN on itself, sending flames shooting high into the sky. Frank lies back, floating on the water, the rain pelting around him, letting the miracle of it all, take him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Little Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens again.  Time stutters and repeats.  As if the sprockets were caught in the projector. CRASH!  The GLASS SHATTERS AGAIN!  CRASH...CRASH... Camera ratchets into the exploding storm of the flying gl ice and whiskey.  And then time stops as we hold close on frozen shard - in it, the cracked reflection of John's ey The camera moves through the reflection and into.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S EYE
dialogues.text: A burst of light and then...distorted images.  Like looki at reflections through a smashed mirror.  The cracks gel, we are in... MONTAGE.  A SERIES OF QUICK FLASHING IMAGES. 1969: Frank, Johnny, Butch and Satch at the World Series. 1971: Johnny and Gordo sitting on Frank's lap, at the Ham 1972: Frank and Johnny, playing catch. 1976: Johnny winning a swimming race at Longbranch Boys C Frank cheering. 1984: Frank, Julia and Satch beaming with pride as John graduates from the police academy. These images appear as DISJOINTED FRAGMENTS OF NEW MEMORI A PAST THAT DIDN'T EXIST BEFORE.  A past where Frank Sull didn't die in that fire. It's like watching random frames from the Sullivan Family 8mm home movies as John's brain struggles to absorb decad of NEW MEMORIES in the span of seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normal vision slowly returning.  The broken glass is rock on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.  John, you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Longbranch...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not looking too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, I just...I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father didn't die in a fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father didn't die in a fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire?  What are you talking about?  He had cancer, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cancer.  It was the cigarettes.  Right? The cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, lung cancer.  Ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand shaking, John takes a long sip of his beer.  Gor and Satch exchange a concerned look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you outta lay off a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo, I wasn't dreaming.  I talked to him, it was real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ham radio.  That's how come he didn't die in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loaded silence.  Three guys looking at each other, thin very different things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio mic) Johnny?  Johnny?  You there?  C'mon, Chief, answer me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but static.  Frank jiggles the frequency dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief? (louder) Chief, are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  And then a voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right here, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank turns.  Johnny, sleepy faced, wrapped in his blanki stands just outside the room - he looks a little scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Chief. (beat) C'mere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny shuffles over, Frank lifts him up on his knee - brushes the hair out of his face...and gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streetlights flood the tree-lined street.  Frank & Johnny standing next to the little red bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
